newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian central bank says no rate cut in January.
newsitem.headline: Croatian central bank says no rate cut in January.

text.p: Croatia's central bank said on Thursday it would leave key interest rates and the reserve requirement unchanged in January after a series of small cuts last year.
"There will be no change to monetary policy instruments in January," governor Marko Skreb told a news conference.
The discount rate has been 6.5 percent for the past few months and the benchmark Lombard rate for lending to banks with liquidity problems stands at 11 percent.
The National Bank of Croatia gradually trimmed the reserve requirement in 1996, bringing it down by some six percentage points to 35.85 percent of kuna deposits in the banking sector.
"This trend will continue this year to an extent allowed by other monetary developments," said vice governor Relja Martic.

Commercial banks have to redeposit around 40 percent of foreign exchange funds abroad, but Martic said the central bank might also consider lowering this ratio later in the year. -- Kolumbina Bencevic, Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
